Award.AwardTitle: IRES: U.S.-Czech Research Experience for Students on Wide Bandgap Materials for Energy and Biosensing Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This U.S.-Czech International Research Experience for Students (IRES) project provides graduate and undergraduate students from North Carolina State University (NCSU) and nearby U.S. universities, North Carolina A&T and Shaw, with early career international research experience at the Czech Academy of Sciences' Institute of Physics, in Prague. The goal is to contribute to a diverse and globally-engaged science and engineering workforce by providing eighteen U.S. student participants, six annually, with the opportunity to pursue mentored research on wide bandgap materials, i.e., nitride and oxide semiconductors materials. At the Czech partners' institute, each participant will gain hands-on experience with advanced characterization techniques. Overall, the research objectives of this IRES project are to study the fundamental and growth related properties of novel wide bandgap semiconductor materials, to identify current technology challenges, and investigate approaches for problem solving. Such materials are of interest because they exhibit promise for future use in devices that would be capable of operating at high power and high frequency, and in harsh atmospheric conditions or biocompatible environments.

Under the direction of Principal Investigator Tania Paskova and her Czech counterparts, participant research activities span materials science, surface science, semiconductor physics, and chemistry. The intent is to work cooperatively to increase our fundamental understanding of the inherent electrical, optical and surface properties of wide bandgap materials as well as their modifications, following a variety of chemical treatments to examine their potential and limitations for energy and biosensing applications. The new knowledge and improved understanding of the surface properties, polarity, and doping effects in wide bandgap materials with different crystallographic alignments are expected to contribute to future applications, including power electronics, optoelectronics, and chemical and biological sensors. The early career international research experience will expose the U.S. students to current technology challenges and increase their awareness of the importance of novel materials for areas essential to our future quality of life.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This International Research Experience for Students (IRES) program provided U.S. undergraduate and graduate students from North Carolina State University (NCSU) with early career research experience at the Institute of Physics, Academy of Science at Czech Republic (ASCR). The overall goal of the IRES program was to educate more inclusive and globally-engaged science and engineering individuals, reflecting the strength of the diverse U.S. population and capable of operating in the international research environment and the global market. The goal was also to provide the students participating in this project with a global perspective and opportunities for professional growth through international cooperative research training and mentoring. During focused summer projects, the IRES participants were involved in materials science research and gained hands-on experience with advanced characterization of wide bandgap materials for energy and biosensing applications.

 

The specific research objectives were:

- MOCVD growth optimization of nitride based device structures – Investigate the excitonic emission of MOCVD grown InGaN/GaN multi quantum well structures and explore their applicability for fast scintillator applications.

- XPS and Raman scattering study of functionalized semipolar (10-11) GaN Surfaces - Investigate and compare the surface compositions of semi-polar Gallium Nitride with and without the functionalization of different adsorbates using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy.

- Micro-Raman, XPS, and KPFM study of functionalized AlxGa1-xN surfaces - Investigate and compare the surface chemistry of AlxGa1-xN with and without functionalization with various chemical adsorbates.

- Dielectric and conducting properties of b-Ga2O3 - Execute THz spectroscopy measurements at lower frequencies using impedance spectroscopy and analyze experimental data.

- Effect of chemical modification on the surface properties of AlxGa1-xN substrates with gradient aluminum composition - Investigate and compare the surface composition of AlxGa1-xN before and after functionalization by different chemical adsorbates.

- Effect of chemical treatments of nanostructured GaOOH nanoparticles – Execute Raman, photoluminescence, XPS, and SEM experiments in order to understand the properties alteration of GaOOH nanoparticles modified with different porphyrin dyes.

 

The scientific results of these research efforts were published in seven joined publications in peer- reviewed journals:

Bartoš, O. Romanyuk, J. Houdkova, P. P. Paskov, T. Paskova, and P. Jiricek, Electron band bending of polar, semipolar and non-polar GaN surfaces, J. Appl. Phys. 116 (2016) 105303, http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4943592

Bartoš, O. Romanyuk, J. Houdkova, P. P. Paskov, T. Paskova, and P. Jiricek, GaN quantum dot polarity determination by X-ray photoelectron diffraction, Appl. Surf. Sci. 389 (2016) 1156-1160, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2016.07.169

B Bartoš, O. Romanyuk, T. Paskova, and P. Jiricek, Electron band bending and surface sensitivity: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of polar GaN surfaces, Surface Science 664 (2017) 241-245 http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.susc.2017.07.003

P.J. Snyder, H. Davis, N.G. Berg, B. Pearce, O. Romanyuk, P. Jiricek, T. Paskova, and A. Ivanisevic, Passivation of semipolar (10-1-1) GaN with different organic adsorbates Materials Letters 236 (2019) 201-204, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matlet.2018.10.109

W. T. Adams, N. R. Vinueza, O. Romanyuk, I. Gordeev, T. Paskova, and A. Ivanisevic, Nanostructured GaOOH modified with reactive yellow, red and blue water-soluble dyes, AIP Advances 9, 025005 (2019); doi: 10.1063/1.5080353

S. Gleco, O. Romanyuk, I. Gordeev, K. Kuldová, T. Paskova, and A. Ivanisevic, Modification of the surface properties of AlxGa1-xN substrates with gradient aluminum composition using wet chemical treatments, ACS Omega, 4, (2019) 11760-11769, DOI: 10.1021/acsomega.9b01467

N. Blumenschein, C. Kadlec, O. Romanyuk, T. Paskova, J.F. Muth, and F. Kadlec, Dielectric and conducting properties of unintentionally and Sn-doped β-Ga2O3 studied by terahertzs spectroscopy, J. Applied Physics 127, (2020) 165702;  doi.org/10.1063/1.5143735

 

The knowledge acquired under this project contributed to better understanding of surface properties, defects, dopants, scattering processes in nitride and oxide wide bandgap materials. While these wide bandgap materials have been established as viable alternatives for UV optoelectronics and power electronic applications, their possible application for detection and sensing devices remains to be better explored and the research executed under this project was linked to this effort.

The international experience ensured by this project was part of the overall training and the PhD thesis of seven students. The participants were given unique opportunities to travel abroad, to get access to different facilities and to interact on daily basis with highly qualified team of mentors who provided them with unique experience with an important and lasting effect on their professional carriers. Overall, the IRES project helped place them in a good competitive position in the labor market of advanced semiconductor manufacturing.
